text: <extra_id_0> Latent membrane protein 1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> of Epstein-Barr virus interacts with <extra_id_0> JAK3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and activates STAT proteins .

<extra_id_0> Latent membrane protein 1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> LMP1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) acts like a permanently activated receptor of the tumor necrosis factor ( TNF ) - receptor superfamily and is absolutely required for B cell immortalization by Epstein-Barr virus .

Molecular and biochemical approaches demonstrated that <extra_id_0> LMP1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> usurps cellular signaling pathways resulting in the induction of NF-kappaB and AP-1 via two C-terminal activating regions .

We demonstrate here that a third region encompassing a proline rich sequence within the 33 bp repetitive stretch of <extra_id_0> LMP1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> 's C-terminus is required for the activation of <extra_id_0> Janus kinase 3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> JAK3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) .

The interaction of <extra_id_0> LMP1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> JAK3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> leads to the enhanced tyrosine auto / transphosphorylation of <extra_id_0> JAK3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> within minutes after crosslinking of a conditional <extra_id_0> NGF-R <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> : <extra_id_0> LMP1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> chimera and is a prerequisite for the activation of STAT transcription factors .

These results reveal a novel activating region in the <extra_id_0> LMP1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> C-terminus and identify the JAK / STAT pathway as a target of this viral integral membrane protein in B cells .
